title: 114_hr5144
content: The Act may be cited as the "Jumpstart Housing Opportunities Utilizing Small Enterprises Act of 2016" or the "Jumpstart HOUSE Act of 2016." It introduces new tranches of capital for successful state programs. Section 3003 of the State Small Business Credit Initiative Act of 2010 is amended to include definitions for 'eligible participating State' and 'unused funds' related to the allocation and competitive awards. The Secretary will allocate $500,000,000 among eligible participating States based on the 2010 allocation ratios. States must apply within 6 months of the enactment of this subsection to receive funds. The Secretary will transfer allocated funds to eligible participating States once they have expended, transferred, or obligated at least 80 percent of the last \1/3\ of the 2010 allocation. The funds allocated to eligible participating States under this paragraph shall not amend or modify existing Allocation Agreements related to the 2010 allocation. Transferred funds must be used appropriately by eligible States. An eligible participating State can use transferred funds for authorized purposes under subsection (c)(3). If the State has not spent at least 80 percent of the last \1/3\ of the 2010 allocation within 2 years of approval, the funds will no longer be available. Any amounts allocated to an eligible participating State under this paragraph may not be transferred and shall be available to the Secretary for making awards under paragraph (4). After 2 years, any amounts allocated to a State that is not eligible will be reallocated. The Secretary may award competitive funding from the amount available under paragraph (6)(D) on a competitive basis. The Secretary may award up to $1 billion to participating States and consortiums for authorized purposes. Participating States must submit an application by a specified deadline to be considered for an award. The Secretary may require information in applications from participating States. Each State or consortium can submit only one application. Non-participating States can apply to become participating States. Factors are considered in the decision-making process. When deciding on awarding funds to a State or consortium, the Secretary considers how they plan to use the funds to leverage private sector capital, create jobs, and serve businesses. The Secretary considers various factors when awarding funds to a State or consortium, including the establishment of a self-evaluation system and the provision of non-Federal funds. The Secretary awards funds to States or consortiums based on factors like self-evaluation systems and non-Federal funds. Funds are transferred in two tranches, with 50% given initially and the rest later. After a State or consortium certifies spending 80% of the initial transfer, the Secretary will provide the remaining award amount. The State must contribute at least 10% of the activity costs funded by the award. The Secretary may determine State contributions qualifying as part of the State share of costs. Unused funds can be awarded competitively to participating States for authorized purposes. The Secretary will decide if allocated funds to a State are no longer available if not used. The Secretary may determine State contributions as part of the State share of costs. Unused funds can be awarded competitively to participating States for authorized purposes. If a State has not expended 80 percent of the second \1/3\ of the 2010 allocation by December 31, 2016, the funds will be made available to the Secretary for awards. States must submit an application to receive an award under this paragraph. The Secretary may award funds competitively to participating States, with a minimum amount of $5,000,000. Compliance and reporting requirements must be met by participating States. During the 8-year period after receiving funds, participating States must submit quarterly and annual reports as per section 3007. States can use up to 3% of funds for administrative expenses. During the 1-year period after enactment, the Secretary may enter into contracts to carry out the program. Any transferred amounts to States shall not be considered assistance for certain purposes. $1.5 billion is appropriated to the Secretary for program administration costs. The Secretary may enter into contracts to administer the program for 8 years, with $1.5 billion appropriated for costs. SEC. 3. SUPPORT FOR AFFORDABLE HOUSING PROJECTS. Section 3003(c) of the State Small Business Credit Initiative Act of 2010 is amended to provide funds to small businesses for affordable housing projects for low- or moderate-income households. The text chunk discusses using funds for affordable housing projects for low- or moderate-income households, including covering contributions required under certain provisions and purchasing foreclosed properties for specified purposes. The text chunk outlines the definition of "small business" under the Small Business Act and the use of funds for affordable housing purposes by participating States. The State must use a minimum of either $2,500,000 or 10 percent of the unobligated amount for purposes described under paragraph (3)(C) from the date of enactment.
